nodes.text: The widespread use of constant elasticity of substitution (CES) functions in integrated assessment models (IAMs) causes a modeling artifact that produces monotonically and exponentially increasing carbon prices during long-term energy transitions, misrepresenting technical substitutability and leading to misleading policy implications

CES functions are share-preserving and imply that as an incumbent factor has a large initial share, exponentially increasing amounts of the alternative factor are required to substitute it while maintaining constant output
Technological substitutions historically follow S-curve diffusion with dynamically changing (increasing then saturating) elasticity of substitution, not the constant elasticity implied by CES
IAMs commonly combine nested CES and CES variants across economic and energy production modules, extending CES beyond its original labor-capital context into long-term technical substitution modeling

The CES-driven artifact of exponentially rising carbon prices produces three policy harms: price diversion (overreliance on price-setting over physical planning), sticker shock (resignation due to seemingly infeasible carbon prices), and technological myopia (preference for technologies already represented in model shares)

Analytical properties of the two-input CES show MRTS depends on the ratio of inputs and elasticity parameter, yielding decreasing marginal rate of technical substitution and exponential requirements of the substitute input as substitution progresses
A derived carbon tax expression from CES shows carbon price grows exponentially as the fossil share declines and is highly sensitive to the elasticity parameter and initial shares
Empirical literature and historical data document S-curve diffusion and learning-by-doing in energy technology transitions, with accelerating substitution and falling costs as penetration increases

Case studies of modern IAMs and hybrid models (e.g., GTEM-C, MIT EPPA, GCAM, MERGE) show nested CES structures in industrial and energy modules and report exponentially rising carbon prices in scenarios

Stylized CES examples calibrated to realistic initial fossil shares produce implausible physical substitution trajectories (e.g., needing many times more renewable energy to reduce fossil share by modest amounts) and carbon taxes orders of magnitude above substitute technology costs

Mathematical demonstration: solving CES Lagrangian for energy produced by fossil (F) and renewable (R) yields PF/PR = alpha/(1-alpha) * (F/R)^{-rho-1} and price elasticity equal to -1/(1+rho), implying the modeled sensitivity and exponential price paths

Comparison of CES-derived behavior with empirical S-curve evidence and IAM outputs indicates the CES formulation produces artifacts inconsistent with historical substitution dynamics and technology cost trajectories

These policy harms can lead to suboptimal policymaking such as overemphasis on very high future carbon prices, underinvestment in deployment targets and physical system planning, and reliance on incumbent-biased options like CCS, nuclear, or biomass

A feasible mitigation in IAMs is to use dynamically varying elasticity of substitution calibrated to observed technology diffusion (linearly or exponentially decreasing rho) to replicate S-curve transitions within existing frameworks

A more fundamental recommendation is to adopt modeling approaches based on physical energy principles and explicit techno-physical system representations rather than relying solely on economic CES aggregation for long-term energy transition analysis

Limitations: CES correction via dynamic elasticity is a pragmatic compromise but does not substitute for high-resolution physical energy models; IAMs also face external limitations such as discounting choices, uncertain climate damage functions, and valuation of nonmarket impacts
